4:14 basically we also have to apply the chain rule on 2^x as well, but x'=1 so in case of f(x) =2^x it would be f'(x)=ln2*2^x*1 which could be left as ln2*2^x since 1 is the neutral element in terms of multiplication. It's not a big deal, but I guess it should be mentioned for people who may ask why we wouldn't (seemingly) apply the chain rule on 2^x.

= 1/(x⁵) because of the derivative of ln(x), then multiply by the derivative of x⁵ which is 5x⁴ because of the chain rule.  So: = 1/(x⁵) • 5x⁴ = (5x⁴)/(x⁵)

Yes, he has studied medicine 💊. 😊

You have a product of two functions, and you are interested in finding the derivative.   Use the product rule.  First times derivative of second, plus second times derivative of first.  first function = ln(x) second function = sin(x) derivative of first = 1/x derivative of second = cos(x)  Construct it according to the chant: first*derivative of second + second*derivative of first ln(x) * cos(x) + sin(x)*1/x  Conclusion: ln(x)*cos(x) + sin(x)/x
Could you please explain the 3rd one as well?​ @carultch

@BestVersion-lz2oi  No problem.  This one uses both the product rule and the chain rule together.  Given: x^2*ln(x^5)  The derivative of the ln(x^5) part uses the chain rule.  To remember the chain rule, just treat the Leibnitz notation as a fraction.  Given f(g(x)), its derivative is df/dg * dg/dx.  As you can see, dg/dg cancels, and we're left with df/dx.   Treating Leibnitz notation as a fraction doesn't always work, so you'd need a more formal proof to show that you can do it, but in this case it does, and there is a formal proof to the chain rule.  Thus, we evaluate: derivative of outer as function of original inner, all times derivative of inner function.   d/dx f(g(x)) = f'(g(x))*g'(x).  Inner function: x^5.  Call this g. Outer function: ln(g) Derivative of outer: 1/g Derivative of inner: 5*x^4.  Drop the exponent by 1, and have old exponent join the coefficient.  Thus: d/dx ln(x^5) = 5*x^4 * 1/(x^5), which simplifies to 5/x  Again, recall the chant: "First times derivative of second, plus second times derivative of first." first function = x^2 second function = ln(x^5) derivative of first = 2*x derivative of second = 5/x  Construct product rule result: x^2*5/x + 2*x*ln(x^5)  And simplify: 5*x + 2*x*ln(x^5)

The x is outside of the ln argument.  Only the 5 is inside it.   It is a misleading notation.  Due to the fact that there are no parenthesis to indicate the input to the logarithm, you proceed until you get to the next operation, and assign that as the input of the function.   Once you hit the next operation, in this case multiplication indicated by a dot, you stop the input to the logarithm, and have that operation take place after the logarithm is calculated.
